introduction.p: In this chapter we will focus on common accompanimental textures. This chapter does not make an attempt to catalog every known accompanimental texture. Instead, it is meant to encourage you to listen to texture more closely and increase your musical awareness.

section.title: Texture
section.p: We will consider texturetexture in terms of vertical and horizontal elements. The vertical nature of texture relates to the number of notes occurring simultaneously as harmonies. It could also relate to the number of voices or instruments performing melodies simultaneously in a contrapuntal texture. The horizontal element of texture relates to rhythmic activity: is the most common rhythmic value in a passage a slow or fast one?
To illustrate, here is a texture with chords (vertical elements) containing five voices with a melody (a sixth voice) above. Notice that the texture has slow rhythmic values on the horizontal plane.

figure.caption: Samuel Barber, Adagio for Strings (1936)

section.p: Our second example is an excerpt for four instrumentsa string quartet. While this a four-voice texture, it is full of rhythmic activity. The most common rhythmic value is the sixteenth note, and the syncopated figures in measures 34 of the Violin I part and measures 56 of the Viola part add to the textural complexity.

figure.caption: Mozart, String Quartet K. 428, IV (1783)

section.p: In the following sections, we will examine fairly straightforward melody-and-accompaniment textures in classical and popular music. In later chapters we will explore more complex textures.

section.title: Chorale Texture
section.p: Chorale textures are those in which there is a chord for every (or nearly every) melody note. A familiar example of chorale texture is the Star-Spangled Banner.

figure.caption: Francis Scott Key and John Stafford Smith, The Star-Spangled Banner (1814)

section.p: In the following example by Schubert, the melody at times moves in a slightly different rhythm that the chords below.

figure.caption: Franz Schubert, Winterreise, D.911, Die Nebensonnen (1828)

section.p: Chorale textures are also described as homorhythmic because all of the parts move in the same rhythm.

figure.caption: Jeff Bhasker, Nate Ruess, Andrew Dost, Jack Antonoff, Some Nights (2011)

section.p: In the next section we will examine arpeggiated accompaniments.

subsection.title: Arpeggios
subsection.p: One way to express chords rhythmically is through arpeggios in one part and a bass line in octaves in a lower part, as in the following example from Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata.

figure.caption: Ludwig van Beethoven, Moonlight Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2, I (1802)

subsection.p: The next example has descending arpeggios.

figure.caption: Alicia Keys, If I Ain't Got You (2004)

idx.h: If I Ain't Got You (Alicia Keys)

subsection.p: Notice that in both the Beethoven and Alicia Keys examples there is the harmonious interval of a tenth (an octave plus a third) between the bass (lowest) voice and the soprano (highest) voice.
The following examples have arpeggios that ascend and descend through a chord.

figure.caption: James Pankow, Colour My World (1970)
Fred Ball, Joseph Angel, and Robyn Fenty, Love on the Brain (2016)

subsection.p: Notice in the above example that there is also an organ playing block chords to create a sense of legato in the texture.
The next two examples are from more recent popular music.

figure.caption: Adele Adkins and Dan Wilson, Someone Like You (2011)
Ryan Tedder, Secrets (2009)

subsection.p: Below is an example in with arpeggios in sixteenth notes.

figure.caption: Kevin Briggs, Kandi Burress, Tameka Cottle, Lisa Lopes, No Scrubs (1999)

subsection.title: Alberti Bass
subsection.p: Alberti bass accompaniment patterns involve arpeggios that do not arpeggiate chords in a simple upward or downward motion, but in a lowhighmiddlehigh pattern as you can see in the examples below.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 545, I (1788)

subsection.p: The next example uses the same Alberti pattern as in the Mozart example above, but transposed to E minor and in a lower register.

figure.caption: Brian Carman and Bob Spickard, Pipeline (1962)

introduction.p: This section contains the following subsections below:

subsection.title: The 1 (2) & Rhythm
subsection.p: In this section, we will discuss some accompanimental rhythms that occur frequently in popular music. The first such rhythm has two chords per measure, with the first chord on beat 1 and the second chord on the upbeat after beat 2.

figure.caption: Marvin Gaye and Ed Townsend, Let's Get It On (1973)

subsection.p: You will find a similar rhythm and bass line in the next example.

figure.caption: Ed Sheeran, Thinking Out Loud (2014)

subsection.p: The 1 (2) & rhythm is also found in Don’t You (Forget About Me), a song associated with the film The Breakfast Club.

figure.caption: Keith Forsey and Steve Schiff, Don’t You (Forget About Me) (1985)

subsection.p: Below are five more examples of block chord accompaniment in the 1 (2) & rhythm.

figure.caption: Holly Knight, Gene Bloch, Ann Wilson, and Nancy Wilson, Never (1985)
Kesha Sebert, Lukasz Gottwald, Benny Blanco, Tik Tok (2009)
Bruno Mars, Philip Lawrence, Christopher Brown, James Fauntleroy, Johnathan Yip, Ray Romulus, Jeremy Reeves, Ray McCullough II, That's What I Like (2017)

subsection.p: Notice that the example above (That's What I Like) has the same progression as September by Earth, Wind, and Fire.

figure.caption: Charlie Puth, Cameron Thomaz, Andrew Cedar, Justin Franks, Dann Hume, Josh Hardy, and Phoebe Cockburn, See You Again (2015)

idx.h: See You Again (Wiz Khalifa ft. Charlie Puth)

figure.caption: James Arthur, Neil Ormandy, Steve Solomon, Say You Won't Let Go (2016)

idx.h: Say You Won't Let Go (James Arthur)

subsection.p: The example below has the 1 (2) & rhythm in dimininution.

figure.caption: Justin Bieber, Benny Blanco, and Ed Sheeran, Love Yourself (2015)

subsection.title: The Barbara Ann Rhythm
subsection.p: It is easier to describe the next block chord accompaniment pattern as the Barbara Ann rhytm than the 1 2 3 (4) & (1) & (2) & 3 rhythm. Below are six examples of pieces that use this rhythm, whether with block chords or solely in the bass line.

figure.caption: Fred Fassert, Barbara Ann (1961)
Brian Holland, Lamont Dozier, Eddie Holland, You Can't Hurry Love (1966)
Sara Allen, Daryl Hall, and John Oates, Maneater (1982)
Kimberley Rew, Walking On Sunshine (1985)

idx.h: Walking On Sunshine (Katrina and the Waves)

figure.caption: Nic Cester and Cameron Muncey, Are You Gonna Be My Girl (2003)

idx.h: Are You Gonna Be My Girl (Jet)

subsection.p: A slower version of this rhythm occurs in Deep Purple’s Smoke on the Water.

figure.caption: Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Gillan, Roger Glover, Jon Lord, and Ian Paice, Smoke on the Water (1973)

subsection.title: Repeated 8th-note Chords
subsection.p: Repeated 8th-note chords occur regularly in classical music textures.

figure.caption: W.A. Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 310, I (1778)
Franz Schubert, Winterreise, D. 911Gute Nacht (1828)
Robert Schumann, Dichterliebe, Ich grolle nicht (1844)

subsection.p: The next example is from the musical Annie. Note the 1 (2) & rhythm in the bass line.

figure.caption: Charles Strouse and Martin Charnin, Annie, It's the Hard Knock Life (1977)

idx.h: It's the Hard Knock Life (from Annie)

subsection.p: Repeated eighth notes are a standard accompanimental texture in rock.

figure.caption: Geoff Gill and Cliff Wade, Heartbreaker (1979)

subsection.p: The repeated eighth-note rhythm is also common in recent popular music. Note that the following example uses the 1950's progression (i.e., ).

figure.caption: Nate Ruess, Andrew Dost, Jack Antonoff, and Jeff Bhasker, We Are Young (2011)

subsection.title: Repeated Quarter-note Chords
subsection.p: Repeated quarter-note chords are a common accompanimental rhythm in classical and popular music.

figure.caption: George Frideric Handel, Ombra mai fu, Xerxes, HWV 40 (1738)
Joe Raposo, Jon Stone, and Bruce Hart, Can You Tell Me How to Get to Sesame Street? (1969)

h.q: Can You Tell Me How to Get to Sesame Street?

figure.caption: Billy Joel, She's Got a Way (1971)
Lou Gramm and Mick Jones, Cold As Ice (1977)
Gordon Sumner, Roxanne (1978)
Michael Bublé, Alan Chang, and Amy Foster-Gillies, Haven’t Met You Yet (2009)
Sara Bareilles, Love Song (2007)

subsection.p: In the next section, we will examine accompanimental textures consisting of afterbeats and offbeats.

subsection.title: Afterbeats
subsection.p: The term afterbeats is from Fundamentals of Musical Composition by noted composer and pedagogue Arnold Schoenberg. Afterbeatsafterbeats are repeated chords (usually eighth notes, sometimes quarter notes) that occur after the downbeat.

figure.caption: Ludwig van Beethoven, Piano Sonata Op. 2, No. 1, IV (1796)

subsection.p: In the next example, the afterbeats are not repeated chords but instead are passing-tone figures harmonized in thirds.

figure.caption: W.A. Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 279, III (1775)

introduction.p: Offbeatsoffbeats are typically chords that occur regularly on upbeats, avoiding downbeats. While there are many styles of music that use chordal offbeats, in this section we will consider only polka and reggae styles.

subsubsection.title: Polka
subsubsection.p: The polka, which originated in Bohemia, has connotations with Germary and Oktoberfest. The polka in the United States is often associated with Frankie Yankovic, who was known as the Polka King.

figure.caption: Jaromír Vejvoda, Beer Barrel Polka (1927)

subsubsection.title: Reggae
subsubsection.p: Reggae is associated with the island of Jamaica and, in terms of texture, is characterized by offbeats, often played on an electric guitar. Bob Marley is closely associated with reggae music.

figure.caption: Bob Marley, Could You Be Loved (1980)

subsubsection.p: By the late 1970s, British bands like The Police and UB40 were recording songs that used the reggae accompanimental style.

figure.caption: Gordon Sumner, Walking on the Moon (1979)
Neil Diamond, Red Red Wine (recorded in 1983 by UB40)

subsubsection.p: Reggae accompanimental texture is fairly common in the present day, as can be heard in the following examples.

figure.caption: Gwen Stefani and David Stewart, Underneath It All (2001)
Jason Mraz, I'm Yours (2007)
Nasri Atwey, Adam Messinger, Mark Pellizzer, Ben Spivak, Alex Tanas, Rude (2013)

introduction.p: The 32 son clave (and the 23 son clave) 32 son claveare essential rhythmic elements in Afro-Cuban music. In this section we will see how cross rhythms implied by the 32 son clave can be viewed as a possible source of cross rhythms in popular music. Here is a video demonstration of a 32 son clave.
Here is rhythmic notation of a 32 son clave. Notice there are three attacks in the first measure and 2 attacks in the second bar.
The rhythm underlying the first bar is 3+3+2.
The 32 son clave has also been called the Bo Diddley BeatBo Diddley beat because of its use by Bo Diddley in the 1950s. Look at the rhythms shown above as you listen to the following examples.

figure.caption: Willie Dixon, Pretty Thing
Bert Berns, Bob Feldman, Jerry Goldstein, and Richard Gottehrer, I Want Candy
Russ Ballard, New York Groove

idx.h: Back in the New York Groove (Ace Frehley)

figure.caption: George Michael, Faith
U2, Desire

introduction.p: In the examples below, only the first bar of the 32 son clave is used. Below, the 3+3+2 rhythm is shown in both eighth notes and sixteenth notes. The sixteenth-note version is known as tresillo.
The example below shows the sixteenth-note subdivisions in the 3+3+2 rhythm.
Below are different ways of notating the sixteenthnote version 3+3+2 rhythm.
The first example, by the Rebirth Brass Band, uses a second line drumming pattern, which is associated with second line parades in New Orleans.

figure.caption: Reggie Calloway, Casanova (1987)

introduction.p: The well-known introduction to Eye of the Tiger uses the 3+3+2 rhythm.

figure.caption: Frankie Sullivan and Jim Peterik, Eye of the Tiger (1982)

introduction.p: In the following example from Cyndi Lauper's Girls Just Want to Have Fun, the lead electric guitar riff emphasizes a 3+3+2 rhythm in 16th notes on each downbeat.

figure.caption: Robert Hazard, Girls Just Want to Have Fun (1983)

idx.h: Girls Just Want to Have Fun (Cyndi Lauper)

introduction.p: Below is an example showing the 3+3+2 rhythm (in 16th notes) immediately repeated. The rhythm is shown in two possible notations below.
The following three examples all use the (3+3+2)+(3+3+2) rhythm as a rhythmic ostinato or groove.

figure.caption: John Stephens and Toby Gad, All of Me (2013)

introduction.p: Notice that this progression is from the Best-Seller progression.

figure.caption: Shawn Mendes, Teddy Geiger, and Scott Harris, Treat You Better (2016)
Ed Sheeran, Steve Mac, Johnny McDaid, Kandi Burruss, Tameka Cottle, and Kevin Briggs, Shape of You (2017)

introduction.p: This rhythm also occurs in the following classical piece by Ligeti.

figure.caption: György Ligeti, Trio for Violin, Horn, and Piano, II (1982)

idx.h: Trio for Violin, Horn, and Piano, II

introduction.p: The following examples have the (3+3+2)+(3+3+2) rhythm in 8th notes.

figure.caption: Guy Berryman, Jonny Buckland, Will Champion, and Chris Martin, Clocks (2003)
Grohl, Hawkins, Mendel, Shiflett, Best of You (2005)
Nasri Atwey, Adam Messinger, Mark Pellizzer, Ben Spivak, Alex Tanas, Rude (2013)

subsubsection.title: Habanera and Reggaeton
subsubsection.p: The reggaeton beat is built from a 3+3+2 rhythm. We will see a relationship between the reggaeton beat with the habanera. First, let us examine the famous Habanera bass line from the opera Carmen.

figure.caption: Georges Bizet, Carmen, Habanera (L'amour est un oiseau rebelle) (1870)

idx.h: Carmen, Habanera (L'amour est un oiseau rebelle)

subsubsection.p: Compare the habanera pattern above to the reggaeton beat below, notated for bass drum and snare drum.
Compare the reggaeton rhythm to the 3+3+2 of the first bar of a 32 son clave (refer to the second measure in the example below).
Here are examples of songs with a reggaeton beat.

figure.caption: Wycliffe Johnson and Cleveland Browne, Dem Bow (1990)
Aubrey Graham, Paul Jefferies, Noah Shebib, Ayodeji Balogun, Luke Reid, Errol Reid, Kyla Smith, Corey Johnson, One Dance (2016)
Luis Rodríguez, Erika Ender, and Ramón Ayala, Despacito (2017)

subsubsection.p: Notice that the progression for Despacito comes from the Best-Seller progression.

figure.caption: Bieber, Michaels, Tranter, Moore, and Tucker, Sorry
Karen Marie Ørsted, Jonnali Parmenius, and Uzoechi Emenike, Final Song (2016)
Adam Levine, John Ryan, Jacob Kasher Hindlin, Justin Tranter, and Phil Shaouy, Cold (2017)

subsubsection.p: In the next two sections, we will examine expansions of the 3+3+2 rhythm

subsection.p: In this section, we will see each number in the 3+3+2 pattern repeated, generating the 3+3+3+3+2+2 pattern.
Listen for the 3+3+3+3+2+2 rhythm in the following examples.

figure.caption: U2, Beautiful Day (2000)
Aluna Frances and George Reid, You Know You Like It (2012)

idx.h: You Know You Like It (Aluna George, DJ Snake Remix)

figure.caption: Janee Bennett, Jessica Glynne, Jack Patterson, and Ina Wroldsen, Hold My Hand (2015)

subsection.title: 8 Groups of 3 Plus 4 Groups of 2
subsection.p: the 3+3+2 pattern can also be expanded to 8 groups of 3 sixteenth notes followed by 4 groups of 2 sixteenth notes, as shown in the example below.
Listen for this rhythm in the examples below.

figure.caption: Ray Parker, Jr., Ghostbusters (1984)
Pink, Max Martin, Johan Schuster, Raise Your Glass (2010)
Too Many Zooz, Warriors (2016)

subsubsection.title: Other Combinations of 3s and 2s
subsubsection.p: You will also find other combinations of 3s and 2s (or 3s and 4s).

figure.caption: Stefan Gordy, Skyler Gordy, David Listenbee, Peter Schroeder, Party Rock Anthem (2011)

subsubsection.p: Notice that this progression is from the iVIIVIVII progression. The rhythm in the above example is dissected below.
Listen for the 3+3+4+3+3 rhythm in the following examples.

figure.caption: Onika Maraj, Nadir Khayat, Carl Falk, Rami Yacoub, Wayne Hector, and Bilal Hajji, Starships (2012)
Max Martin, Savan Kotecha, Ilya Salmanzadeh, Amethyst Kelly, Ariana Grande, Problem (2014)

subsubsection.p: One also finds the 3+3+4+3+3 pattern in the second bar of Tik Tok, an example from earlier in the chapter.

figure.caption: Kesha Sebert, Lukasz Gottwald, Benny Blanco, Tik Tok (2009)

subsubsection.p: Notice that this progression comes from a rotation of the iVIIVIVII progression.

introduction.p: Sometimes the identity of a song is in its repeated bass line (known as a riff, which is a short repeated pattern). Listen to the distinctive bass lines in the following examples.

figure.caption: Joseph Eastburn Winner, Little Brown Jug (1869)
Lennon-McCartney, Day Tripper (1965)
Bernard Edwards and Nile Rodgers, Good Times (1979)
John Deacon, Another One Bites the Dust (1980)
Rick James, Superfreak (1981)
David Bowie, Under Pressure (1981)
Amethyst Kelly, Charlotte Aitchison, George Astasio, Jason Pebworth, Christopher Shave, Kurtis McKenzie, Fancy (2014)
Ben Haggerty, Ryan Lewis, Jacob Dutton, Eric Nally, Joshua Karp, Joshua Rawlings, Darian Asplund, Evan FloryBarnes, Tim Haggerty, Downtown (2015)

subsection.title: Distinctive Guitar Riffs
subsection.p: You will also find distinctive riffs played by guitar in conjunction with bass, as in the following examples.

figure.caption: Ray Davies, You Really Got Me (1964)
Jimmy Page and Robert Plant, Immigrant Song (1970)
Steven Tyler and Joe Perry, Walk This Way (1975)
Angus Young, Malcolm Young, and Brian Johnson, Back in Black (1980)

subsection.p: This chapter is meant to give you ideas about animating chords and chord progressions with accompanimental textures, including riffs. It is by no means meant to be exhaustive, but rather to encourage you to listen closely to texture and accompaniment.
